Award.AwardTitle: Improving Vocabulary Learning through Working Memory Training: Examination of Causal Effects and Learning Trajectories

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
One of the biggest challenges in education is promoting oral language development. In particular, vocabulary learning is key for the development of higher-order oral language and literacy skills. New insights from theory and evidence-based approaches will help children build this foundational skill which in turn will ensure success in school. To this end, researchers will examine the extent to which vocabulary learning is influenced by a cognitive factor (i.e., working memory) and an environmental factor (i.e., input frequency and quality). The two primary goals are to develop and examine the feasibility of implementing working memory training for young children, and to develop working memory training on vocabulary learning, with the potential of mitigating effects of impoverished input often associated with children from low socio-economic (SES) backgrounds.

This project focuses on the causal role of cognition (i.e., working memory) in vocabulary learning for young children. In the first year, the researchers will develop several child-friendly and engaging working memory training modules to examine whether working memory training improves vocabulary learning in general, as well as working memory for children from low SES backgrounds. In the second year, the training modules will be implemented in a small-scale pilot trial where children are randomly assigned to four conditions: (1) working memory training; (2) vocabulary training; (3) combined training on working memory and vocabulary; and (4) business-as-usual control. The findings are expected to provide proof-of-concept for development of a causal model of working memory in vocabulary learning, which can inform the development and design of interventions to improve vocabulary learning.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project Outcomes Report: NSF Award # BCS-1729039

Project Title: Improving Vocabulary Learning through Working Memory Training: Examination of Causal Effects and Learning Trajectories

Recipient Organization: University of California, Irvine

Project/Grant Period: 8/15/2017 to 7/31/2020

PI: Young-Suk Kim

One of the foundational skills in daily interactions, academic achievement, and career is oral language skills. In particular, vocabulary is the core of oral language. Vocabulary also plays a key role in reading and writing development, and academic achievement.

This project focused on the causal role of working memory in vocabulary learning for children. We developed working memory and vocabulary instruction materials that are suitable for kindergartners, and examined whether it is feasible to implement them for kindergartners, and whether working memory training causally improves vocabulary learning. We developed three tablet-based working memory games that are engaging and challenging. We also developed vocabulary instruction using evidence-based best practices. These instructional materials were implemented with kindergartners who were randomly assigned to different experimental conditions. Some children received working memory instruction only; some children received vocabulary instruction only; some children received both working memory training and vocabulary instruction in two different time conditions; and other children played tablet-based games that are not related to vocabulary or working memory. We found promising results for the combined working memory and vocabulary instruction on children?s vocabulary learning.

The project allows us to test a causal model of vocabulary learning and cognitive underpinnings of vocabulary acquisition ? whether vocabulary learning is causally influenced by working memory as well as instruction. It is well-established that vocabulary learning is influenced by environmental factors such as the quantity and quality of verbal interactions and instruction. The role of the child?s working memory in vocabulary learning has been primarily supported and investigated using correlational data.  

Understanding causal mechanism in vocabulary learning has considerable implications in education and society as vocabulary plays a key role in literacy development and academic achievement. A theory- and evidence-based innovative approach to build vocabulary will help children start on strong ground for their learning and success in school. The project provides critical insights to developing and designing vocabulary interventions in order to promote successful vocabulary development for children of varying needs. Our findings will have particularly important implications for children who are arrive at school with less-than-ideal language skills and vulnerable populations such as those from low socio-economic backgrounds, and those with language impairments and learning disabilities.
